 I read the entire KJV three times (except the "begats" - I could only handle reading those twice) during my time as a Christian - the first 20 years or so of my life.
 
 In fact, it was my reading of the Bible that ended up leading to my deconversion (I am an atheist).
 
 I am completely convinced that if everyone in America were to read the Bible, the whole thing, really read it carefully and thoughtfully, then there would be fewer Christians as a result. 
 
 I'm constantly amazed (though I should be used to it by now) how little so many Christians actually know about their Bible. Few people, if anyone at all, become Christian from reading the Bible. They become Christians because of what their parents taught them, or from being befriended in a time of need by a Christian community, or some other relationship of that sort, and learned in the context of those relationships how they were "supposed" to read and understand the Bible. But reading the Bible (and going beyond those imposed strictures on how to read and understand it) has led to many Christians becoming former Christians.
 
 
 But back to my original point - which Bible? Since my deconversion, I still have had interest in religion, and have read all of the Protestant Canon and the apocrypha in English (thus the Catholic Canon). I read the other books of the Orthodox Canon, too. Gnostic canon.
 
 Read the Jewish Canon in English, much of it in Hebrew, a less in German and Greek.

 I haven't focused on christianity, however - I've read many other "Holy books".

 I have read very little of the old testament apart from a passing, non-religious interest in what it said while I was a teenager.
 
 The reason? It's just never been a part of my life, it's never been important to me. I am aware that it informs much of our literary culture and I intend to read it cover to cover before my time here is over, much as I intend to read the Koran and other religious texts.
 
 The new testament I know a little better, because I went to Sunday School (don't know if you have same name for it in the US, but there must be similar things, it's for little kids to be indoctrinated into Christianity) when I was young. Not because my parents are religious, they just wanted me to have access to it so I could make my own mind up.
 
 I remember quite clearly, I must have been 8 or 9, realising that the whole 'God' thing was basically the same as the whole 'Santa Claus' thing. Honestly. I asked my parents at that age "Why do people read this book?" and they gave me a nice, ambiguous, good-parent answer along the lines of "Well, no-one knows for sure" etc. 
 
 I think the key factor for me was talking to this kid at my school whose family were Hindu. I then asked my parents about this and discovered the panoply of world religions, at which point I realised I had no reason to believe any of them over the others. This made a massive, indelible impression on my developing mind.
 
 In response to your OP, I would not personally criticise the Bible itself (see I even automatically capitalize it!). However I can never understand people who see it as anything other than what it so obviously is: Just another ancient collection of poetic, romanticised history intertwined with allegorical morality tales and lists of rules drawn up by a small tribal culture, that by historical providence happens to be one of the few that has survived to the present in some form. 
 
 So I do plan to read the thing, but I do not need to read it, any more than I need to read the Hindu Vedas or ancient Roman or Greek polytheistic philosophy, to know that it is just another cultural artefact, a testament to man's tribal and superstitious nature, a necessary cry for meaning in a world of irrational mysticism and ignorance.

I for one have not only read the bible but studied it as well in seminary. (No, I'm not a preacher/priest.)
 
 I am sure that those who wrote or scribed the bible were sincere people with their own "bents" on life. 
 
 I see inspiration as a prisim. A prisim reflects true light into many colors. Although the light may be pure, each sees it in different colors depending upon your position to see it.
 
 There is a great deal of evidence pointing to the fact there are at least 2 creation stories in Genesis. It is believed by most theological scholars that the creation stories were a result of many scribes meeting together, trying to explain creation as they saw it. Some believed in the first story, others believed in the second story. So, both were captured in the book.
 
 The greatest problems with the scriptures are the readers of the scriptures. . .the fundamentalists who recite each and every verse as "gospel." Facts are that when looking at history during that period many of the stories related to the then and there, not the future or now. Revelations can also be explained as well for that period, not for a future period.
 
 The book of Isaiah was written by at least two different writers. Most fundamentals disagree with this as well however, the scribes who wrote book referred to two completely different periods of history and again have two distinct writing styles.
 
 Many believe that John, the disciple wrote the Revelations. Not true. The writing style is different and, if that was John, when on Patmos, he lost his mind and then wrote the book.
 
 So, is the bible the "Word of God"? I don't think so. Men wrote the different books of the bible and ascribed the words to God for the purpose of making them laws, rules and words to live by. The bible was written as an inspiration for the people of that time, not necessarily for us today. The stories in the bible testify to this fact. They didn't have supernatural powers of seers, suthsayers or psychics. They could not see into the future any more than you or me. It even states in the bible that we are not to be seers, suthsayers or psychics. Go figure.
 
 If you notice, dogma, the larger point here, always is accompained by egos; who is right, who is wrong; I believe this way and he doesn't so one of us has to be wrong. The bible states that God is not the author of confusion. Then why are there so many different opinions on a single verse or chapter? Too many believe in the bible so much they forget to treat their brother with love, dignity and respect. In other words, the bible is more important than people. Big mistake.
 
 Dogma requires apologists to attempt to "explain" the obsurdities in the bible.
 
 This is my opinion and I'm sticking to it!:)
